newsitem.title: CANADA: Thirsty Canadians guzzle Hibernia production.
newsitem.headline: Thirsty Canadians guzzle Hibernia production.

text.p: Production from Canada's first major offshore oil project is still a few months off, but Hibernia barrels are already flooding the market.
True to Canadian form, the wildly popular production is amber and sudsy, not black and gooey.
Hibernia Beer, launched in May to mark the christening of the C$5.8-billion ($4.2 billion) oil project's platform, is being guzzled at a rate that continues to surprise its St. John's-based brewer.

Original plans for the lager, which has a picture of the huge oil platform on the label, were to sell it for about two months, David Fong, president of Quidi Vidi Brewing Co., said in a telephone interview.
But thanks to the huge demand, the microbrewer now expects to make it a permanent product, said Fong, adding that almost 20,000 dozen bottles have been sold so far.
The brew is currently sold only in Newfoundland, where the Hibernia project has been a shot in the arm for a battered local economy.
"But having said that, there's been plenty of it drunk out in Calgary, in Houston and in Princeton, N.J. -- the big oil execs have been having them flown in," said Fong.
The first oil production from the Hibernia project -- Canada's first major offshore petroleum development -- is expected in December.
Its partners include Petro-Canada, Mobil Corp. unit Mobil Oil Canada Ltd., Chevron Corp. unit Chevron Canada Resources Ltd., Murphy Oil Corp., the Canadian government and Norsk Hydro A/S .
Peak output is expected to be 135,000 barrels a day -- of oil, not beer.
